attachments.title: The AI Research Paper Was Real. The ‘Coauthor’ Wasn't
attachments.text: An MIT professor found his name on two papers with which he had no connection. A different paper listed a fictitious author by the name of "Bill Franks."
attachments.fallback: Wired: The AI Research Paper Was Real. The ‘Coauthor’ Wasn't

text: I can’t believe such a fraud. I mean, it is obvious when someone finds out and the reputation of the true authors just go down the drain. Why would anyone take such a risk?

elements.text: I can’t believe such a fraud. I mean, it is obvious when someone finds out and the reputation of the true authors just go down the drain. Why would anyone take such a risk?

text: Also, Why would anyone make up a fake co-author?

elements.text: Also, Why would anyone make up a fake co-author?

text: Clout/prestige/to slip past peer review easier/etc

elements.text: Clout/prestige/to slip past peer review easier/etc

text: But does having more co-authors help in getting reviewed easily?

elements.text: But does having more co-authors help in getting reviewed easily?

text: If you have a heavily credentialed coauthor (ivy league school) it can put the peer reviewers more at ease. Unless they want to put that person down. If it's a peer reviewer who doesn't exist/have adversaries... maybe?
